awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Graph Signal Sampling: Theory and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern society is increasingly reliant on large scale, distributed, interconnected, and  complex systems, such as the Internet, smart grids, intelligent buildings or highways. Furthermore, much of the information now being generated is also interconnected in complex ways (e.g., the Web).  While these systems and datasets can be monitored by recording relevant data, the volumes of such data make it difficult to address critical tasks, such as anomaly detection, in a timely manner. These datasets often exhibit a natural graph structure, with graph nodes representing measurements or information (e.g., the temperature of a sensor or data from a web page), and graph edges representing the  relationships between nodes (e.g., distance between sensors or links between webpages). This project develops novel methods for sampling of very large scale graph datasets, with the goal of making it possible to measure only a small fraction of carefully selected nodes, while preserving the ability to analyze the whole system. 

Sampling theory is a major element of signal processing theory and applications, but has only recently been considered for graph signals. While recent progress has been made under the assumption that the graph is fully known, these techniques are prohibitively expensive for practical datasets of interest. This project addresses fundamental questions for the challenging problem of sampling when only partial graph information is available (e.g., decisions based on smaller subsets of connected nodes). For example, given local graph connectivity information and assumptions about the graph signals of interest, such as their frequency localization, the goal is to identify the best set of vertices to sample locally in order to obtain a reliable estimate of the corresponding global graph signals.

por.por_cntn:
Our ability to acquire and store data has increased dramatically in recent years. We may have access to data collected from a large number of sensors distributed an urban area or we may wish to analyze measurements associated to a large scale communications network. In each of these cases, an observation (a signal) is associated to each of the nodes (e.g., sensors) in a network. Once data are captured, the next goal is to extract useful information from it. 

Ideally, if there were no constraints on resources (storage, communications, computation), it would be possible to gather all the observations (i.e., have a complete signal with data from all nodes) and then extract relevant information from what has been measured. In practice, however, gathering observations from every node (e.g., from every sensor in the environment) is too costly. Thus, it is highly desirable to develop methods that can extract the same information from just a subset of observations. 

This grant has focused on developing algorithms, and associated theory, that allow us to optimize the selection of a subset of nodes to be observed, and then extrapolate, from those observations, data at all remaining nodes. For example, when considering a network of sensors, only a small fraction of those sensors needs to be activated at any given time in order to generate measurements, thus reducing significantly communication, storage and computation costs.

We have formulated this a graph signal sampling problem. We construct graphs that represent the relative positions of the points in the dataset. For example, for a sensor network, each graph node corresponds to a sensor with its corresponding measurement, and the edge between two nodes has a weight that decays as the distance between the sensors increases. 

The work funded by this grant has led to advances in the theory and application of graph signal sampling. 

On the theoretical front, we have developed efficient node selection algorithms. That is, we solve the problem of deciding which nodes should be observed in order to maximize the quality of the information obtained. Our algorithm achieves state of the art performance with lower complexity than previously proposed methods. We have also extended these ideas to develop even faster algorithms (with a small penalty in performance). Finally, we have also introduced novel approaches to select nodes when the observation process is unreliable, i.e., some observations may be lost or corrupted.

We have developed Matlab software implementing our proposed techniques and made it openly available (on github). Our work has generated significant interest and follow up work. Since our approach can be applied to generic graphs it can be used for a very broad range of applications, maximizing its potential impact. 

On the application front, we have studied the use of graph signal sampling for  semi-supervised learning. In machine learning tasks such as classification, collecting data can be cheap but labeling it can be very costly. For example, we can browse the Internet to obtain many photos, but labeling the content of those  photos accurately cannot be automated and is expensive and time consuming. In semi-supervised learning, only a subset of data is labeled, reducing the overall cost of training a system significantly. Selecting a subset of data to be labeled can be viewed as a graph signal sampling problem. We have demonstrated that our proposed sampling algorithms outperform existing methods in terms of classification performance. We have also justified theoretically (under some simplifying assumptions) that the optimal data subset chosen based on our proposed sampling methods is also optimal in terms of classification performance. Since semi-supervised learning is widely used across a range of applications, our work can be broadly applied to improve classification performance (or to achieve the same classification performance with a smaller subset of labeled data) in many different applications.
